[[File:Emagicken.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Earring Magic Ken, complete with accessory]]'''Earring Magic Ken''' is a model of the [[Ken (Barbie)|Ken]] doll introduced by [[Mattel]] in 1993 as a companion to its Earring Magic Barbie figure, one of six dolls in the Earring Magic Barbie line.ref{{cite book | last =Jones | first =Amelia | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =The Feminism and Visual Culture Reader | publisher =Routledge | date =2003 | location = | pages =338 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-415-26705-6}}</ref> This iteration of the Ken doll featured an updated look, including blonde highlights in its traditionally brown hair, outfits including purple shirt, lavender vest, a necklace with a circular charm and, as the name indicates, an earring in its left ear.ref name = Lawson{{cite news | last =Lawson | first =Carol | coauthors = | title =Gender-bending playthings challenge industry's toys-will-be-toys tradition | work =New York Times | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =1993-02-27 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref>
Mattel had conducted a survey of girls asking if Ken should be retained as Barbie's boyfriend or whether a new doll should be introduced in that role. Survey results indicated that girls wanted Ken kept but wanted him to look "cooler."ref name = Failures{{cite book | last =Haig | first =Matt | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Brand Failures: The Truth about the 100 Biggest Branding Mistakes of All Time | publisher =Kogan Page | date =2005 | location = | pages =45â€“7 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-7494-3927-0}}</ref> The redesigned Ken was the result. Observers quickly noted the resemblance of Earring Magic Ken to a stereotypical gay man, from the purple clothes to the earring to the necklace, which was described as a "chrome [[cock ring]]."ref{{cite book | last =Paley | first =Maggie | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =The Book of the Penis | publisher =Grove Press | date =2000 | location = | pages =197 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8021-3693-1}}</ref> [[Kitsch]]-minded gay men bought the doll in record numbers, making Earring Magic Ken the best-selling Ken model in Mattel's history.ref{{cite news | last =Melendez | first =Mel | coauthors = | title =Show Me Your Billy | work =Prism | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =Fall 1997 | url =http://web.archive.org/web/19980220181319/http://www.journalism.sfsu.edu/www/pubs/prism/oct97/P1.Billy.html | accessdate = 2007-12-19}}</ref> Despite the commercial success of the doll, public criticism from gay-community commentators such as [[Dan Savage]] in the Seattle, Washington alternative weekly newspaper ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]'' led Mattel to discontinue Earring Magic Ken and recall the doll from stores.ref name = Failures
